title: Small businesses get a boost as ONS moves away from costly monthly surveys
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Wed, Aug 19, 2015, 11:55 BST - UK Markets close in 4 hrs 35 mins Small businesses get a boost as ONS moves away from costly monthly surveys By Peter Spence | Telegraph – 10 minutes ago UBGXF 0.00 
The Office for National Statistics will use VAT data to calculate its economic growth estimates, cutting costs for companies 
Small businesses may no longer have to fill out time-consuming surveys about their activities in a shake-up to the way data about the UK economy is gathered. 
Britain's statisticians will rely less on what business have to say about their activities and more on what the taxman is collecting from them, in an attempt to improve how we estimate the strength of the UK's economy - and cut costs for companies. 
The Office for National Statistics said on Wednesday that it would lean on HMRC data heavily in the years to come, hoping to phase out half of the monthly surveys it sends to businesses by 2020. 
The national statistics office estimates that its plans could save taxpayers in the order of £720,000 a year from using electronic data collection and HMRC data. The changeover would also cut private-sector compliance costs in half, it claimed, while the "most significant savings would be for small and medium-sized businesses". 
Forty-five thousand surveys are currently used each month to gather information on companies that represent around 55pc of the total economy. Using turnover data from VAT receipts filed by eligible businesses should increase that coverage, with around 1.75m companies required to file VAT returns each month. 
Businesses selected for the ONS' electronic data collection programme could be completing returns online as early as spring 2017, the ONS said, which would lead to "significant savings". 
Use of the tax numbers could also mean that economic data is compiled in a more timely and complete fashion. 
In a feasibility study on changing its processes (PDF) , the ONS said that improving the timeliness of regional data in particular would be one large potential advantage, allowing policymakers to more quickly assess which parts of the UK are performing better and worse. 
Nick Vaughan, director of national accounts and economic statistics at the ONS, said: "These plans are part of a wider ONS agenda to develop new and better sources of data and keep producing the highest quality statistics possible." 
Work on developing the new approach began in 2012, when the ONS began a review of the data sources it uses. 
VAT data is supplied under the VAT Act 1994, which allows the ONS to access the figures on the basis of "disclosure of information for statistical purposes (Other OTC: UBGXF - news ) ".
